sentence: 27.1	Objective
Recent attention has been given to the use of technological solutions to ensuring public safety as cities and countries seek to reopen safely amidst the Covid-19 Pandemic.

In particular, the use of temperature screening as a visible effort to identify people who may potentially be infected with COVID-19 has attracted significant attention and debate as to its usefulness and effectiveness as a risk assessment and mitigation measure.
While in some cases the technology has been enthusiastically adopted as a safety measure, it has also been criticised as “notoriously inaccurate” and an ineffective measure.
As is the case with any new technology reaching the public, the legality, practicality, sustainability, and utility of the technology must be assessed.
As is the case with any new technology reaching the public, the legality, practicality, sustainability, and utility of the technology must be assessed.
This study seeks to understand the legality and value of temperature scanning in the employment context.
27.2	Technology

However, many questions remain and must be addressed including: who provides the technology?
Who runs the technology?
Who owns the technology?
How long will the technology be in use for?
The choice of the technology for this case-study comes from its widespread usage already within the first six to nine months of the Covid-19 pandemic within Europe.
As such the legal and ethical ramifications of the technology hold consequences for a great number of employees throughout the Union.
The simplicity of this technology in question also adds to its value as a case study.
As such individuals confronting temperature scanners face a technology which is unlikely to foster fear or uncertainty.
However, even this simple technology creates conditions of disconnect for individuals seeking to control their personal data.

The privacy impacts would change depending on the way in which the scanning takes place.

Specifically this scanning could be (a) conducted by either the employee him/her/themselves or by a supervisor, (b) it could be mandatory or voluntary, (c) the result could be recorded or left unrecorded.

Specifically this scanning could be (a) conducted by either the employee him/her/themselves or by a supervisor, (b) it could be mandatory or voluntary, (c) the result could be recorded or left unrecorded.

On 25 March 2020, the World Health Organisation (WHO) made explicit mention of checking body temperatures of employees daily as one of a number of measures which could help prevent transmission of COVID-19 between employees and make workspaces safer.
Furthermore, the European Centre for Disease Control has referred to temperature checking in the context of screening at airports.

Temperature checking in general has limited value as an estimated 40% of Coronavirus carriers may be asymptomatic or able to transmit prior to the onset of symptoms according to the US’ Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

Personal data that relates to health is increasingly sensitive and is classed as ‘special category data’.
Due to its sensitivity, health data has the protected status of ‘special category data’ under data protection law.
The Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) has issued guidance regarding the processing of special category data in response to Covid-19.

Employment Law Issues

Issues relating to the right to work, the obligation to provide a safe workplace, the right to pay and nature of an enforced absence and recourse are important employment law issues which are directly affected by the use of temperature scanners.
For example, questions such as what happens when an employee registers a high temperature?
And as concerning: what should the employer do if an employee refuses to take the temperature test?

The Belgian Employment Ministry and Data Protection Authority maintain that temperature scanning can only take place voluntarily and no details of the employee’s results can be recorded including the decision for the employee to return home.

The Belgian Employment Ministry and Data Protection Authority maintain that temperature scanning can only take place voluntarily and no details of the employee’s results can be recorded including the decision for the employee to return home.

In its May 2020 Guidance on Consent, the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) makes it clear that consent cannot be lied upon in employer/employee relationships as a significant power differential is present:

In its May 2020 Guidance on Consent, the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) makes it clear that consent cannot be lied upon in employer/employee relationships as a significant power differential is present:

“Given the dependency that results from the employer/employee relationship...Therefore, the EDPB deems it problematic for employers to process personal data of current or future employees on the basis of consent as it is unlikely to be freely given.”
